Award.AbstractNarration:
In August, 2015, the Chinese RMB was devalued, which came as something of surprise to the international financial community and led to dramatic volatility in many markets, including the Chinese. Prior to this devaluation, an experiment was included on the 2014 CCES (Cooperative Congressional Election Survey) that had as its treatment two short vignettes in the guise of news stories (one positive, one negative) about how the Chinese government was managing its currency. Soon after the 2015, this same experiment was repeated using a similar sample. Given the rumored upcoming devaluation of the RMB and the focus of the presidential election on Chinese trade, the same experiment will be repeated as a module of the 2016 CCES. This study will allow the study of how framing of an issue, experimentally, affects how people understand and evaluate China in a variety of ways. It also allows us to examine different conditions under which people react and how these conditions impact their reactions. This includes the previous experiments prior to a devaluation and soon after a devaluation and now during a presidential election cycle.

The intellectual merit of this project is two-fold. First, there is the original, direct idea, of having the opportunity to study how the framing of an issue, experimentally (and now, with full control condition), affects how people understand and evaluate China in a variety of ways. The second idea is to repeat a survey and an experiment about Chinese currency and its possible management before the respondents could realistically know that the Chinese might actually do so, but could only guess, and guess during a congressional election, with a variety of claims in the "air" about China. We then repeat it while there is news coverage available that is close to the experimental treatment, per se, and then repeat it again (it is assumed) once that coverage is well past, but when in the middle of presidential election campaign (and thus are likely to get mostly a presidential level set of messages about China from the two parties, rather than a more diffuse and not so nationally focused). Rarely, is there such an opportunity to have a before, during, after trial. Rarely do we also have the opportunity to address how framing might work, given different background information in the actual political environment. The broader impact of the study will be an extension of the understanding of how Americans view the "rising of China," as it becomes ever more newsworthy. And, in particular, the ability to see how malleable perceptions and evaluations are, as they are buffeted about by real events in China, by domestic politics, and by the framing of news coverage.

POR.DRECONTENT:
China's emergence as a budding global power marks one of the most important changes in the international setting over the last few decades.  Americans have observed this emergence and developed perceptions, beliefs, and values about China.  My research, of which this grant was a part, has shown that Americans do have real attitudes about China, but those attitudes are pliable.  The research from this grant was about this pliability.In this project, I conducted a survey experiment in 2014 that randomly provided different accounts of China's role in (potentially) manipulating its currency for its own political and economic gain.  This experiment was embedded in a nationally representative survey of U.S. citizens.  By fortunate coincidence, the first application of this survey-embedded experiment happened a short while before China actually did face a currency crisis that led them to take actions that some, including U.S. politicians, explained as currency manipulation, while others explained China's actions as ordinary government policies to avoid negative economic consequences inside China itself.  I was able to repeat the experiment just after the currency crisis itself unfolded (in 2015), while media coverage was fresh and ongoing.  This project supported a third round of the survey experiment (in 2016), after the crisis.  Consequently, I was in the fortunate position of conducting the experiment before, during, and after the event.The results were, first, that overall feelings about China have been and continue to be less positive than Americans feel toward other even reasonably comparable nations, including Russia.  Second, with respect to the question of how well the description that China "manipulates its currency" for its own gain, most Americans thought that China was willing to manipulate its currency for its own good, likely at the expense of other nations, notably the U.S.The experiment consisted of giving randomly selected respondents either “positive” or “negative” news about China’s actions, in which negative news was that they were manipulating their currency to take advantage of other nations, while the positive treatment reported that China was taking actions to ensure their economy stayed strong.  In all three waves, the experiment “worked.”  That is, those who received the positive treatment thought better of China in this regard than those who received the negative treatment.  In the pre-crisis wave, the effect was fairly small and was significant only after the 2016 midterm elections, suggesting that the U.S. media coverage of China in the election helped shape voter expectations about China, by setting a context in which they were more sensitive to relevant information.  The 2015 survey experiment, which happened during the currency crisis, had stronger effects than in 2014, but it was the 2016 survey experiment, conducted during and after the American elections that had the largest and most systematic effects.  Not only were all treatments statistically significant, but the size of their effects are significantly larger than in 2015, and some of those, in turn, were significantly larger than in 2014.Americans thus appear to be suspicious about the motives of the Chinese government, at least with respect to this one dimension of economic policy.  This suspicion is enhanced during times when the Chinese government is in the news, either literally (as in the during- and after-currency-crisis survey experiments) or experimentally (because the survey respondents are randomly assigned different news accounts).  Further, embedded in a news environment that features China, the public’s opinions are more sensitive to additional news – the experimental treatments more strongly shaped opinions in those cases.  Finally, it appears that domestic politics, notably the 2016 presidential campaign in which Trump claimed that China was responsible for numerous economic (and other) ills, including that China manipulated it currency, heightened this sensitivity even further.One final empirical finding is one might have expected that the experimental treatment might have had effects on a number of aspects of American’s evaluations of China.  There was, for example a question evaluating respondents’ perceptions of China’s economy overall (in addition, there were a number of other, non-economic evaluations).  Only in the 2016 survey did the experimental treatment help shape how respondents viewed China’s economy overall, and it appeared to shape little else.  This finding suggests that future research should seek to establish just how Americans’ understanding of particular aspects of China shapes their overall evaluations of the nation.  As noted, at least prior to the on-going investigation of Russian influence, Americans had more negative views of China than Russia.  On-going assessments are needed to understand why that might be the case, whether campaign discourse has long-term effects on public opinion, and whether it matters, in behavior as well as attitudes, that China is seen less than positively.  Finally, more direct assessment is needed to understand how candidates and officeholders shape those perceptions in the long term.
